title-group.article-title: Polyvinylbutyral-assisted synthesis and characterization of mesoporous silica nanofibers by electrospinning route

abstract.p: In this study, mesoporous silica nanofibers were synthesized from tetraethylorthosilicate in a mixture of ethanol, hydrochloric acid, water and polyvinylbutyral PVB as precursor, via a simple sol–gel and electrospinning route. Hexagonal silica nanofibers were obtained by annealing treatment at 850°C for 12 h. The morphology, crystal structure, and particle size of fibers have been characterized by scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, thermogravimetric analyzer, energy-dispersive spectrometer, X-ray diffraction, and Fourier transform–infrared spectrometer. The pore structures were characterized by the N2 absorption–desorption isotherm.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The design and preparation of one-dimensional (1D) nanostructures on the nanoscale and microscale has attracted considerable attention because of their unique properties and potential applications.1–3 Many materials found in nature exhibit combinations of properties not found in engineered materials. The mesoporous materials with highly ordered structure can be functionalized not only for catalysts but also for sensor, electronic, and photonic devices.4–6 Surfactant–template-ordered mesoporous silica materials with uniform larger pore size and high-surface area have attracted much attention for their potential applications.

Silica materials are extensively employed to support metal catalysts. The increased surface area of silica materials with a tubular structure in the nanometer regime might lead to unpredictable improvement regarding the catalytic effects. Functionalized mesoporous silica networks may have the potential to be developed as dual-phase materials, and several infiltrated compositions primarily developed for catalysis applications due to their high-surface area have been reported in the literature.7–10

Of the many methods used nowadays for the fabrication of 1D nanostructure materials, the use of sol–gel and electrospinning technique is one of the most promising methods.11 Recently, research on the synthesis of various ceramics and metal-oxide nanofibers via sol–gel and electrospinning is rapidly growing.12,13 Electrospinning route is a simple, versatile, and relatively inexpensive technique for the synthesis of broad range of ceramic nanofibers. Unlike other methods that produce short nanorods or nanotubes, electrospinning produces continuous nanowires and nanotubes. Although electrospinning has been used mainly for the fabrication of organic polymeric nanofibers, ceramic metal oxide nanofibers have also received considerable interest because of their potential applications in areas including photovoltaic devices, piezoelectric material, gas sensors, and solar cells.14–17 The commonly used polyvinylbutyral (PVB) acts as mesoporous template. PVB is a nontoxic, odorless, and environment-friendly polymer, and it is widely used as functional materials in various fields.18 Also, because of its good compatibility with inorganic materials, PVB is an excellent organic component for the fabrication of organic/inorganic hybrid composites.

In this study, we investigated the relationships between the pore size and thickness of functionalized mesoporous silica nanofibers, which have been directly synthesized by the electrospinning, and examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) surface area, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA), energy-dispersive spectrometer (EDS), and Fourier transform–infrared spectrometer (FT–IR).

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
Tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS; Shanghai Chemical Reagent Company Ltd.) and ethanol absolute were from PA Panreac. Hydrochloric acid was obtained from Panreac. Polyvinylbutyral (PVB) (average Mv ∼ 40 kDa) was obtained from ChangChun Group Company. The schematic setup of the electrospinning route used in the study was shown in Figure 1. Silica precursor was dissolved in solvent mixtures of TEOS/ethanol/water/HCl with the ratios of 1/4/4/1(w/w) when its concentration is fixed at 10 wt%. Homogeneous solutions of silica precursor were prepared by adding PVB at 15 wt% concentrations with gentle magnetic stirring at ambient temperature for 1–2 h. The solutions were prepared and used immediately for electrospinning. About 1 mL of solution was placed in a glass tube with a 0.21 mm inner-diameter tip. Aluminum foil was used as the collector and connected to the ground. The concentration dependence of solution viscosity was higher for the PVB solutions than the aqueous solutions. This may be due to the more expanded conformation of silica in the aqueous media caused by the electrostatic repulsion between partially charged silica molecules. In the electrospinning of polymer solutions, the fiber formation process can be characterized by the formation and thinning of the liquid jet to the solidification and deposition of fibers on the collecting target. A stainless steel electrode was connected to a high-voltage power supply (You-Shang Technical Corp.), which can generate DC voltage up to 30 kV. The supplied voltages between the tip and collector were set at 10 kV with a tip-to-collector distance of 8 cm. The applied voltage first overcomes the liquid surface tension to from a jet, which then bends and spirals into a larger looping path as the jet thins into finer fibers and solidifies. The first step of annealing at 500°C for 6 h in air could be attributed to the decomposition of PVB. The second step of annealing at 850°C for 12 h was assigned to the amorphous–crystalline transformation at a heating rate of 2°C/min to obtain pure crystalline silica (β-quartz) nanofibers. Figure 1.
Schematic diagram of electrospinning device.

sec.title: Instrumentation
sec.p: The as-prepared samples were characterized by XRD, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), TGA (Perkin Elmer, STA6000), and FT–IR (Hitachi 270-30 I. R. spectrophotometer), respectively. XRD was carried out on a Shimadzu, LabX XRD-6000 X-ray powder diffraction with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The scanning rate of 0.02 s−1 was applied to record the patterns in the 2θ range of 15–85°. TEM characterization was taken on a JEM-2000EX, using an accelerating voltage of 160 kV. Hitachi S-4200 A SEM at an acceleration voltage of 5 kV was employed to characterize the morphologies. The viscosities of solutions were measured with a LVDV Brookfield viscometer. N2 absorption–desorption isotherm was measured with BEL JAPAN, BELSORP mini II equipment at −196°C. Before analysis, the samples were first degassed at 160°C for 8 h. The surface area was calculated according to BET equation and pore size obtained from the desorption branch of isotherms using Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) approach.

sec.title: Morphologies of electrospinning nanofibers formation
sec.p:
Electrospinning fibers obtained from 15 wt% PVB/silica mixture solution at 10 kV with a tip-to-collector distance of 8 cm with various concentrations. A typical SEM image for the products is shown in Figure 2(a). The image shows that large quantities of wire-like nanostructures were formed. Their length ranges from several tens to several hundreds of micrometers. The typical widths of the nanofibers are in the range of several tens to several hundreds nanometers. The typical TEM image of the as-prepared products was shown in Figure 2(b). Both kinds of the fibers appeared uniform in size and had smooth surfaces. The average diameter of porous silica fibers was about 80 nm. It can be seen that after the anneal treatment, the diameter of the fibers decreased was caused by the removal of PVB. Figure 2(b) shows a typical bright-field TEM image of the amorphous silica nanofibers. The surfaces of these nanofibers are smooth and have a porous structure. Both the morphology and size determined by SEM are similar to those of the TEM results. Figure 2.
(a) SEM images of silica nanofibers by electrospinning (scale bar is 5 µm) and (b) TEM images of silica nanofibers by electrospinning (scale bar is 20 nm). The inset in (b) shows the SAED pattern recorded from the same nanofibers.

The formation of mesoporous involves the following steps: first (Equation (1)), the cationic surfactants associated with the counterions to form Si–OH, and hydrolysis of Si–OEt occurred. Second (Equation (2)), the condensation reaction occurs on the Si–OEt-associated micelle surface. The condensation rate chiefly depends on the association of Si–OEt formation. When enough silicate condensation has occurred, the long polysilicate would act as a bridge to bring the cylindrical micelles together to form the mesophase separation. (1) (2) (3)

Based on the reaction thermodynamics, the Gibbs free energy of the substitution reaction is given −1031.567 kcal/mol,19 Finally (Equation (3)), the first step of annealing at 500°C for 6 h in air could be attributed to the decomposition of PVB. The second step of annealing at 850°C for 12 h for the complete conversion of pure crystalline silica (β-quartz) nanofibers. In this study, we have used the hydrolyzed silicate sol in PVB–ethanol (15 wt%) solution for electrospinning to prepare PVB/silica composite fibers. Upon calcinations of the above composite fibers in air, the pure silica fibers were formed.

The effect of parameters of solutions on the morphology of resulting viscosity and conductivity of PVB/silica fibers with different ratios was examined, as illustrated in Figure 3. Figure 3 shows fibers containing, respectively, 5, 11, 13, 15, and 20 wt% of PVB polymer with respect to the weight of silica. Silica fibers without any PVB showed beaded morphology due to the low molecular weight and low viscosity of the sol–gel silicates in the spinning solution (8 cP). On the other hand, the long molecular chains of the PVB polymer, when added to the spinning solution, tend to get entangled with the smaller silica sol molecules forming covalent bonds via the cross-condensation of the silanol groups (i.e., Si–OH) in both TEOS and PVB.20 Silica fibers with 15 wt% PVB show a uniform morphology with an average diameter of around 80 nm. As the wt% of PVB is increased from 15 to 20 wt%, the viscosity of the spinning solution also increases from 182 to 1480 cP, which in turn increases the diameter of the fibers from 80 to 450 nm. It was found that the viscosity increased as the concentration of polymer solution increased from 5% to 20% due to the higher number of polymer chain entanglements. The increase in diameter of fibers with viscosity has been noticed previously in many electrospinning polymer fibers.21 On the other hand, when the viscosity further increased, the conductivity of fibers decreased. The results showed that high-conductivity preferred electrospinning.22 The high-conductivity solvent is helpful to the ion diffusion and reduces resistance. The high-viscosity solvent can cause the condition that the diffusion of ions is not easy, to reduce the conductivity.23 The solution conductivity is one of the main parameters in the electrospinning process since the viscous polymer solution is being stretched due to the repulsion of the charges present on its surface, and more charges can be carried at higher solution conductivity.24 This result indicated that the conductivity of the polymer solution is one of the key factors in the production of uniform electrospinning PVB/silica nanofibers. Figure 3.
Viscosity and conductivity of PVB/silica precursor with various concentration ratios.

Figure 4(a)–(d) shows SEM micrographs of the electrospinning PVB/silica fibers at four different applied voltages, 10, 12, 14, and 16 kV. When a high voltage is applied, the pendent drop of the PVB/silica hybrid solution at the nozzle of the spinneret will be affected by two competitive forces: the surface tension and the electrostatic force. When the applied voltage is increased to the threshold value, a droplet of hybrid solution at the tip is deformed into a conical shape known as Taylor cone. In this case, positive charge or dipole orientation will be formed at the interface between the droplet and air. When the applied electric voltage defeats the surface tension of the hybrid solution, one or several jets of the solution are ejected from the tip of the Taylor cone and fly toward the grounded plate. This electrified jet then undergoes a stretching and whipping process, leading to the formation of a long and thin thread. With the increase of the voltages applied to the solution in a certain range, the electrostatic force is larger than the surface tension, and the fibers become thicker. It is observed that the diameter distribution of the silica fibers is shifted to the smaller size as the applied voltage decreases. The most population is in the range 70–150 nm for the silica fibers synthesized at 10–16 kV. As a result, the silica nanoparticles with positive charges were repulsed by the positive charges on the surface of fibers and they aggregated in the middle of fibers owing to the electrostatic repulsion. Furthermore, the high electric field induces the polarization and orientation of silica nanoparticles; thus, the silica nanoparticles dispersedly embedded in and aligned along the fiber direction.25 The variation in fiber diameter of PVB/silica with applied voltage is shown in Figure 4(e). As the applied voltage increases, the electrostatic forces acting on the polymer drop also increase, which provides an additional force to overcome the viscoelastic and surface tension forces exerted by the polymer solution. Thus, increasing electrospinning number should increase the elongation of the polymer chains in the jet and produce a finer fiber.26 Figure 4.
SEM images of PVB/silica fibers (bar = 5 µm) electrospinning from different voltages are (a) 10 kV (b) 12 kV (c) 14 kV (d)16 kV, and (e) dependence of PVB/silica nanofibers size on voltages.

sec.title: Thermal behavior
sec.p:
Figure 5 shows TGA thermogram of the silica fibers obtained at 10 kV. It is observed that the weight decreases substantially at the low-temperature region and decreases continuously; 13 wt% PVB/silica fibers (Figure 5(a)) showed three steps and a total loss of ca. 56.6%. The first step of ca. 6.7% from 100°C to 310°C could be attributed to the desorption of the water, and the second significant weight loss of ca. 38% between 320°C and 460°C was assigned to the decomposition of PVB. From 460°C to 680°C, there was a weight loss of ca. 11.9%, which was assigned to the release of water formed from the condensation of silanols in the silica framework; 15 wt% PVB/silica fibers (Figure 5(b)) showed three steps and a total loss of ca. 62.7%. The first step of ca. 6.7% from 100°C to 310°C could be attributed to the desorption of the water, and the second significant weight loss of ca. 45% between 320°C and 460°C was assigned to the decomposition of PVB. From 460°C to 680°C, there was a weight loss of ca. 11%, which was assigned to the release of water formed from the condensation of silanols in the silica framework. PVB fibers (Figure 5(c)) showed that weight loss began to occur at approximately 340°C and was complete at about 460°C. The temperatures corresponding to peak maxima were near 400°C for ions representing aliphatic species and near 410°C for alkyl aromatics. Figure 5.
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curve of electrospinning: (a) 13 wt% PVB/silica fibers, (b) 15 wt% PVB/silica fibers, and (c) pure PVB fibers synthesized at 10 kV of the applied voltage.

sec.title: FT–IR spectroscopy analysis
sec.p:
The chemical structure of resulting nanofibers at 10 kV was characterized with an FT–IR spectrometer, shown in Figure 6. It is seen that the peaks at 790, 935, and 1043 per cm are assigned to Si–O–Si vibration and the broad band near 3416 per cm to O–H vibration. It should be noted that there is no peak of methyl (CH3) or methylene (CH2) of ethoxy group (–OCH2CH3) in the FT–IR spectrum: typical IR bands of CH3 or CH2 are several strong peaks at 2800–3000 and 1400–1800 per cm regions. This implies that most of the TEOS is hydrolyzed and the ethoxy group is changed to the silanol group (Si–OH). The broad band peak at 3416 per cm results from intra- and inter-molecular hydrogen bonds of the silanol groups. Silica nanofibers were obtained after annealing in air at 500°C, the PVB was removed, and a well-defined fiber texture kept unchangeable. It could be attributed to the interaction of silica with the polymer in the fibers.27 Figure 6.
FT–IR spectrum of silica fibers and PVB/silica fibers synthesized at 10 kV of the applied voltage.

sec.title: X-ray diffraction
sec.p:
XRD is the most convenient and effective tool for the investigation of a crystalline structure. Figure 7 shows the XRD patterns of PVB/silica composites nanofibers produced by electrospinning process before and after annealing. Figure 7(a) is the pattern of sample before annealing treatment. The data in it reveal that the sample is amorphous. On the other hand, Figure 7(b) shows the XRD spectra of silica nanofibers obtained by annealing treatment at 850°C for 12 h, which shows that the 10 major diffraction peaks observed at 20.5°, 26.26°, 41.71°, 45.04°, 49.43°, 54.06°, 58.9°, 66.62°, 72.64°, and 82.17° 2θ can be indexed to the (1 0 0), (1 0 1), (2 0 0), (2 0 1), (1 1 2), (2 0 2), (2 1 1), (2 1 2), (1 0 4), and (3 1 1), respectively. All the diffraction peaks can be indexed as a hexagonal phase of SiO2 (JCPDS 89–8949, β-quartz), which implies that pure SiO2 has been synthesized. The data in it reveal that the sample is crystallization. Initially, a broad reflection characteristic of amorphous silica is observed (Figure 7, bottom). After annealing, strong silica patterns were generated with over 11 matching reflections (Figure 7, top), and a narrow silica reflection becomes visible at 26.65°. The phase transition temperatures of a pure silica system under atmospheric pressure are given as follows.28,29 In the phase change above, α and β represent low- and high-temperature silica phases, respectively. The phase transition temperatures can be affected by the impurities and increased pressures.30,31 The β phases have higher symmetry and lower densities with respect to α phase. All phase transformations are kinetically inhibited and for this reason are influenced by trace of impurities.32 A potential mechanism was derived based on the above results. In the interaction of silica and PVB as the capping agent, the PVB molecules assembled on the surface of silica, making the silica nanoparticles partly covered by PVB long chains. There was also an interaction between silica nanoparticles due to the high Gibbs' surface free energy of silica. The two competing interactions induced larger silica and PVB clusters with various diameters. The surface defects were partly passivated by PVB. With an increase of the reaction concentration, more silica nanoparticles with low aggregation were extracted. The dispersion of the silica and PVB clusters decreased, and the passivation became more effective. Figure 7.
XRD images of mesoporous silica nanofibers by electrospinning route: (a) after and (b) before annealing at 850°C for 12 h.

As shown in Figure 7 for the 15% PVB/silica, the amorphous phase transforms to α-quartz at 500°C with further crystallization to β-quartz after calcinations at 850°C. The width of this peak can be measured and from which a Scherrer fit is used to determine an average grain size of 95 nm. The full width at half-maximum (fwhm) values of the silica nanofibers prove that they are similar to the size calculated by Scherrer equation (D = Kλ/(β cos θ); K = 0.89, λ = 0.15418 nm, β = fwhm, θ = diffraction angle). At this point, the diffraction peaks are narrowed to the instrumental resolution limit and grain size analysis from such data is not feasible. These results illustrate that annealing process is a productive strategy for nanocrystalline silica.

In the case of silica nanofibers, we can also see a very sharp (1 0 1) diffraction peak at 26.65°. D-Spacing values for these XRD peaks were 3.32 Å and a unit cell parameter, a0, of 3.8336 Å was obtained using the following equation:33

For mesoporous silica fibers, a considerable increase in the XRD peak intensity was observed. It should be noted that the intensity increases in the (1 0 1) peak for mesoporous silica fibers after annealing, which provides further evidence of grafting occurring mainly inside the mesoporous channels. Collectively, the XRD pattern of the mesoporous silica fibers also suggests not only a significant degree of short-range ordering of the structure, but also the maintenance of the structural orderness of the synthesized materials after annealing process.

sec.title: Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms
sec.p:
The N2 adsorption/desorption measurement on the calculated materials resulted in type IV isotherms in (a) 5 wt%, (b) 13 wt%, and (c) 15 wt% of PVB polymer with respect to the weight of silica, respectively. The mesoporous silica nanofibers show BET surface area of the range 292.13–312.33 cm2/g. The pore size distribution was calculated based on BJH theory and smaller average diameter and pore volume are in the ranges 2.7459–3.3956 nm and 0.2241–0.2300 cm3/g, respectively. Besides the pore size distribution, PVB had less negative effect on the pore structure of the mesoporous silica fibers. The data obtained together with the calculated unit cell parameter, a0, are shown in Table 1. The porosities, BET surface area, and unit cell parameter are in agreement with the earlier data published for mesoporous silica/PVB. Table 1.

The isotherms exhibited sharp inflection characteristics for capillary condensation within uniform pores, where the P/P0 positions of the inflection points were related to the diameter of the pores. The isotherm represented type IV in the classification of IUPAC and have a H1 hysteresis loop that is representative of mesoporous. The volume adsorbed for all isotherms sharply increased at a relative pressure (P/P0) of approximately 0.4, representing capillary condensation of nitrogen within the uniform mesoporous structure. Wall thickness = 23×d101−BJH average pore diameter

Table 1 lists the BET surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter derived from N2 adsorption isotherms for the samples synthesized in this study. For the samples (Figure 8(a)–(c)) prepared from same reaction condition, pore volume and apparent pore diameter were similar. Under the reaction condition, tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) hydrolyzed and concentrated around the surface of the comicelle to form the wall of the mesoporous silica materials. The cationic polymer acted as a cotemplate to connect the anionic silicates. The cationic polymer played a cotemplate part in the synthetic system, and it was the comicelle that directed the mesopore synthesis. When the TEOS hydrolyzed and interacted with the comicelle, the silica species could penetrate into the interval between the polymer chains. A part of the polymer chains was embedded into the silica framework, which immobilized the polymer in the pore. Figure 8.
Nitrogen sorption isotherm plots of the series of samples a-1 (5 wt%), a-2 (13 wt%), and a-3 (15 wt%) made with different ratios of PVB to silica. Pore size distributions of this series of samples after extraction, calculated using the KJS method assuming cylindrical pore geometry (inset).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, the polyvinylbutyral-assisted synthesis of mesoporous silica nanofibers was done by electrospinning route. A viscous solution of polyvinylbutyral (PVB) was used into the silica precursor, followed by heat treatment temperature at 850°C for 12 h to obtain crystalline silica nanofibers. SEM images show their morphology and the fiber diameter was about 80 nm. The properties of silica/PVB nanofibers produced depend on many process variables including the nanofiber precursor viscosity, the needle inner diameter, the magnitude of the applied voltage and volume feed rate, and the work distance between the needle and the collector. The viscosities all fall within the relatively narrow range of 25–35 cP as well. The result indicated the best processing parameters to electrospinning including the smallest available needle of inner diameter of 0.16 mm; low volume feed rate of 0.1 mL/h; applied voltage of 10 Kv; and tip collector distance of 8 cm; excellent results were achieved. The polyvinylbutyral-assisted synthesis mesoporous silica nanofibers had an average diameter of about 80 nm and the pore diameter of about 2.74–3.39 nm total pore volume was in the range 0.22–0.23 cm3/g and a high specific surface area in the range 292.13–312.33 m2/g. A possible growth mechanism of the uniform nanofibers and the roles are discussed.
